text: Patient: Yeah. We’re going to be cruising in January. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’m sorry. January’s fine. Yeah, that’s fine. Doctor: Okay. Where are you going? Patient: We’re going to ____. We don’t know where. We’re going to so many places. The ship is supposed to stop at Puerto Rico and St. Maarten. So I know those two are . We do a lot of traveling. We just want to get away for a few weeks and we stay in Florida for three weeks and come back. Doctor: Okay, so - Thank you. You like it? Patient: Yes, yes. Doctor: So that’s perfect timing then. I’ll see you around the middle to the second half of January and we’ll check your PSA and your testosterone level at that point, about a week or two before. And I’ll give you a paper printout as well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And hopefully the PSA will still be quite low at that point so we won’t have to take any action. You guys have any other questions you want to ask while we’re getting this done? Patient: No, No, the Lupron, yeah, yeah. Doctor: Perfect. Glad you’re continuing to do well. Again you look pretty well.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: -and that's when it's in the prostate. And that is when you had surgery. Okay, so the treatment here is surgery. And then we have- usually the PSA goes up and then it goes down to zero after you get your prostate taken out. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: And then it'll go back up. That is what we call biochemical recurrence. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And that's when you have a rising PSA but negative imaging. Patient: Mm. Family Member: Okay Doctor: Okay, so that means that because your prostate is out, we know that the PSA is coming from the cancer, but there's not so much of it that we can see it, so it's there somewhere we just don't know exactly where it is. That, you got radiation for back in 2007 because usually, when prostate cancer recurs, it first recurs near the prostate. Am I making sense so far? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Then if it progresses, if you do nothing, you get metastatic disease. And that's when we can see the cancer somewhere in your body either on the CAT scan or the bone scan. So that's a CT or CAT scan or the bone scan because prostate cancer goes to the bone. So when you came to me you already had surgery for localized disease, you had already had radiation, which we sometimes use for our chemical occurrence- Patient: Mm. DOC- but you still had a rising PSA and we weren't sure if you were in this biochemical recurrence bucket or in this metastatic disease bucket. Okay. So, your imaging findings, so your CAT scan here shows…so here are the, this is the summary. I’ll just write summary. We can go through this. So, what this report shows- this is a CAT scan that shows coronary artery calcification, that means there's calcium build up in your around your heart. It's not uncommon for someone your age. Small atrial hernia not important. A thyroid nodule not that important. At some point, we can do a thyroid ultrasound, but we don't need to do anything about that right this moment. So this is what- is is maybe means that it's prostate cancer a small enhancing nodule in the left prostatectomy bed, which may reflect recurrence. So when you look in the full report, what they say is that there is a it's less than once every here is 0.7 by 0.9 centimeters, so then that's like less than one centimeter. So when it's that small, it's like, really difficult. It's actually like impossible to characterize it to say like, yes, this is definitively cancer or this is not cancer. Family Member: Mhm.

text: Family Member: Um now since the cancer has spread, that the main problem Doctor: Uh huh. Family Member: - and the prostate is enlarged. Does it make any sense to remove it? Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
